meanings.definition: To equip or train for war
meanings.sent1: The country decided to militarise its troops for the upcoming conflict.
meanings.sent2: The army base was militarised with advanced weaponry and rigorous training programs.
meanings.sent3: The idea of penguins being militarised for a snowball fight is quite amusing.
meanings.sent4: His mind was militarised with strategies and tactics, ready for any challenge.
meanings.sent5: The sound of drums militarised the atmosphere, signaling the start of battle.

meanings.definition: To give a military character to
meanings.sent1: The general's strict demeanor militarised the entire operation.
meanings.sent2: The camouflage uniforms militarised the soldiers, making them blend into the forest.
meanings.sent3: Seeing a cat with a tiny military hat somehow militarised the situation.
meanings.sent4: The storm clouds militarised the sky, hinting at an impending downpour.
meanings.sent5: The old fort militarised the landscape, standing as a reminder of past conflicts.

meanings.definition: To make military in character or style
meanings.sent1: The new regulations militarised the previously laid-back organization.
meanings.sent2: The architecture of the building was militarised, resembling a fortress.
meanings.sent3: The idea of a militarised cupcake with camouflage frosting is quite amusing.
meanings.sent4: His stern expression militarised his face, showing years of discipline.
meanings.sent5: The music score militarised the film, adding tension to every scene.
